LAINEY WILSON FALL 25 HATS Expand submenu HATS Felt Straw Caps COLLECTIONS Expand submenu COLLECTIONS The Cowgirl Hat C1H  X LAINEY WILSON Felt Straw Western Merch Youth Gift Cards Size Chart Stories About Us / Contact Us At Charlie 1 Horse Hat Company, we specialize in western apparel that breaks the mold. We have something for everyone: traditional cowboy hats for purists, fun yet functional summer hats for beachgoers and road-trippers, and fashion-forward designs for country girls and city folks alike. The straw and felt hats in our collection demonstrate an exquisite eye for detail that shows up in every line, texture, and accent. It’s not just about how our hats look either. Working cowgirls wear Charlie 1 Horse, which means quality, durability, and affordability are built into our manufacturing process. In the same breath, we pride ourselves on being trendsetters, whether it’s on the streets of Nashville, in the fashion houses of Europe, or along the banks of the Pecos River. Charlie 1 Horse hats have shown up on stage, on screen, and in renowned publications such as Vogue since 1978. As of 2024, we are proud to offer our Charlie 1 Horse by Lainey Wilson Collection, where we present designs inspired by the artist’s hit songs and iconic look. Lainey Wilson is not the first country music star to wear Charlie 1 Horse, but she may be our all-time favorite. Whether you are classic country, a rock and roll rebel, or a woman on her way to Cabo or Fiji, Charlie 1 Horse Hat Company has you covered. We invite you to check us out. *One more thing. The Charlie 1 Horse fire brand on your hat’s crowns was hand pressed for a unique, personalized look. An off-center brand is not an imperfection. It is a mark of beauty. To send us a message or to ask a question, please use the chat feature in the bottom right hand corner. You can also email us directly at help@charlie1horsehats.com . We should get back to you shortly during our standard business hours, 9AM – 5PM CST. KEEP ME UPDATED! Charlie Horse restaurant in West Bridgewater to return as Barrett's Alehouse News Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals COUNTY Charlie Horse restaurant in West Bridgewater to return as Barrett's Alehouse Cody Shepard cshepard@enterprisenews.com WEST BRIDGEWATER – The closure was abrupt, leaving many stunned during the summer, but the former Charlie Horse location will soon be filled again. Mike Barrett, the owner of Barrett’s Alehouse, is opening another restaurant at the West Center Street location — and he hopes to be up and running within the next six months. “You won’t be disappointed. It will be a first-class operation,” Barrett recently told West Bridgewater selectmen, as he asked the board to transfer the existing liquor license to his business. The Charlie Horse closed at the beginning of August when co-owner Mary Barrett-Costello cited declining business and the large building, which is 22,000 square feet. But her brother, Mike Barrett, who is no longer part of the family business, is moving in. He owns Barrett’s Alehouse in Bridgewater, North Attleboro and Fall River; Fireside Grille in Middleboro; and Castaways Bar and Grille in Bridgewater. “The standard for granting a liquor license is showing a public need – west of 24, one liquor establishment in the town of West Bridgewater,” attorney Mark Gildea said. “I think that’s some indication of the need for an alcohol establishment in that area.” The restaurant will undergo major renovations before it opens. There will be a second entrance added on the Pleasant Street side of the building to accommodate a new parking lot, for which the plan is still being developed. The bowling alley is being removed and a large function room that can hold 152 people will take its place. The room can also be split into three sections to accommodate smaller gatherings. “They’re going to have a game room that’s a little larger than the existing game room that was there,” Gildea said. The main bar is going to be larger than was at the Charlie Horse and the stage where musicians performed is being removed. The dance floor is also being relocated. The outside patio will have a new layout, but not undergo any structural changes. One of the exterior changes that residents said will make a big difference is blocking the driveway access from the Lowe’s parking lot. People complained of cars speeding through the lot to get into the restaurant parking lot. The restaurant owners are currently working with the property manager to put a fence there so that people going to the restaurant have to use the Route 106 entrance. “We hope to have a similar success. We hope to be there for 25 years,” Gildea said. “The Barretts in all their places become a part of the community and they want to become a part of the West Bridgewater community.” Selectman Jerry Lawrence said the board likes when businesses work together in town and commended Barrett for speaking to other businesses about moving into town. “It’s a great concept and we’re happy to see the building come back,” he said. Selectman Anthony Kinahan asked Barrett if he allows workers to drink while on the job, as he suspected he saw several employees drinking at the Bridgewater location recently. “I would be surprised,” Barrett said, adding he has a zero-tolerance policy. Kinahan also questioned how often police respond to Barrett’s restaurants. The owner said he always has police respond if there’s an issue and that the Alehouse in Bridgewater can have more calls because of live entertainment. “We call no matter what – any confrontation or problem, we call the police and let them deal with it rather than ourselves,” Barrett said. West Bridgewater Police Chief Victor Flaherty said the police response might look bad on paper, but that they hope he does the same in town. “The Barretts have always worked well with police,” he said. “They call all the time. I’d much rather have them do that than hide it.” The three-member board voted unanimously to grant Barrett’s Alehouse the liquor license. Barrett said he originally hoped to open in March or April, but it could be May or June as they need to develop a site plan for additional parking. “The Charlie Horse has always been a great selling point for people to come over – conferences, seminars or retirement parties,” Lawrence said. “When they leave your establishment, they buy their gas in the convenience stores and their goods. It’s a great reason for people to get off Route 24 and stop in town. I think it’s a great proposal.” Careers Staff Directory Accessibility Sitemap Legals Our Ethical Principles USA TODAY Network Style Guide Responsible Disclosure Subscription Terms & Conditions Advertiser Acceptance Policy Terms of Service Privacy Policy California Notice at Collection Your Privacy Choices Contact Us Support Local Business Advertise Your Business Buy and Sell Licensing & Reprints Help Center Subscriber Guide Manage Account Give Feedback Subscribe Today Newsletters Facebook X eNewspaper Archives Jobs Real Estate Classifieds Shopping 10BEST LocaliQ Digital Marketing Solutions © 2025 www.enterprisenews.com.
